etymologies: Old English tæg(e)l, from a Germanic base meaning ‘hair, hairy tail’; related to Middle Low German tagel ‘twisted whip, rope's end’. The early sense of the verb (early 16th century) was ‘fasten to the back of something’

definitions: the hindmost part of an animal, especially when prolonged beyond the rest of the body, such as the flexible extension of the backbone in a vertebrate, the feathers at the hind end of a bird, or a terminal appendage in an insect

examples.text: the dog's tail began to wag frantically

shortDefinitions: hindmost part of animal

definitions: a thing resembling an animal's tail in its shape or position, typically something extending downward or outward at the end of something

examples.text: the trailed tail of a capital Q
the cars were head to tail

shortDefinitions: thing resembling animal's tail in its shape or position

definitions: the rear part of an airplane, with the horizontal stabilizer and rudder

examples.text: the fuselage tapers sharply toward the tail

shortDefinitions: rear part of aeroplane, with tailplane and rudder

definitions: the lower or hanging part of a garment, especially the back of a shirt or coat

examples.text: he stormed off, the tails of his jacket flapping behind him

shortDefinitions: lower part of garment

definitions: a tailcoat; a man's formal evening suit with such a coat

examples.text: the men looked debonair in white tie and tails

shortDefinitions: tailcoat, or man's formal evening suit with tailcoat

definitions: the luminous trail of particles following a comet.
shortDefinitions: luminous trail of particles following comet

definitions: the lower end of a pool or stream

examples.text: shallow riffles and the tails of pools are prime feeding areas

shortDefinitions: lower end of pool or stream

definitions: the exposed end of a slate or tile in a roof

examples.text: the slates are dressed with the beveled tail and edge characteristic of thick, square stone roofing

shortDefinitions: exposed end of slate or tile in roof

definitions: the end of a long train or line of people or vehicles

examples.text: an armored truck at the tail of the convoy

shortDefinitions: end of long train or line of people or vehicles

definitions: the final, more distant, or weaker part of something

examples.text: the forecast says we're in for the tail of a hurricane

shortDefinitions: final, more distant, or weaker part of something

definitions: a person secretly following another to observe their movements

examples.text: I can't put a tail on him, I don't know where he's gone

shortDefinitions: person secretly following another to observe their movements

definitions: a person's buttocks

examples.text: fireworks followed when the coach kicked Ryan in his tail

shortDefinitions: person's buttocks

definitions: a woman's genitals.
shortDefinitions: woman's genitals

definitions: women collectively regarded as a means of sexual gratification

examples.text: I was getting worried that both of us would be chasing tail and getting into trouble for the rest of our lives

shortDefinitions: women collectively regarded in sexual terms

definitions: the reverse side of a coin (used when tossing a coin)

examples.text: the chances of heads and tails in the long run are equal

shortDefinitions: side of coin without image of head on it

phrases.text: with one's tail between one's legs

definitions: follow and observe (someone) closely, especially in secret

examples.text: a flock of paparazzi had tailed them all over Paris

shortDefinitions: follow and observe someone closely

definitions: follow

examples.text: they went to their favorite cafe—Bill and Sally tailed along

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: follow

definitions: provide with a tail

examples.text: her calligraphy was topped by banners of black ink and tailed like the haunches of fabulous beasts
the eight main chapters are topped and tailed with an introduction and an epilogue

shortDefinitions: provide with tail

definitions: (of an object in flight) drift or curve in a particular direction

examples.text: the next pitch tailed in on me at the last second

notes.text: no object, with adverbial of direction

shortDefinitions: drift or curve in particular direction

definitions: join (one thing) to another

examples.text: each new row of houses tailed on its drains to those of its neighbors

shortDefinitions: join one thing to another

phrases.text: with one's tail between one's legs

etymologies: Middle English (denoting a tallage): from Old French taille ‘notch, tax’, from taillier ‘to cut’, based on Latin talea ‘twig, cutting’

definitions: limitation of ownership, especially of an estate or title limited to a person and their heirs

examples.text: the land was held in tail general

shortDefinitions: limitation of ownership
